(Sorry I haven't been posting, It's been a hectic week. I had to reinstall 
my internet server, witch should work bug-free from now on. Sorry I took so 
long to reply^_^)

Tavatron turned, her back to Dinobot. Her shoulders slumped and her ears 
hung limp on either side of her head. She knew what he wanted, why he had 
come. Why couldn�t the past leave her be? No matter where she went, or how 
quickly she could run it always seemed to catch up with her in the end. 
Tavatron crossed her arms and sat beside the cliffs edge, one leg dangling 
precariously over the edge. She just wanted to forget it all. Why couldn�t 
she? The past was always there, lingering in the deepest recesses of her 
mind. Taunting, teasing her. Why wouldn�t it leave her alone?!! Tavatron 
grasped a small stone and hurtled it with all her might over the edge and 
into the forest below.

Tavatron closed her eyes as she tried to regain her composure. Dinobot�s 
slow, steady breathing echoed in her ears. She knew he wanted an answer, a 
reason. It was a merely a question of whether or not he liked what he heard. 
Through closed optics a shadowy image began to focus. The image grew in size 
and intensity until it exploded in a fireball that consumed everything 
within a reasonable radius. Tavatron�s optics snapped open, expecting to 
find a ruined and burning colony. Instead a silent forest met her terrified 
gaze. The wind chilled her sweat dotted body as it blew across the dry 
landscape that surrounded her. Tavatron took several deep breaths before her 
spark beat slowed and she once again was able to regain her composure:

"I expect nothing from you�"

*You have already given me more than you will ever know.*

Tavatron kept this thought to herself. She wanted to tell him just how much 
their friendship meant to her, but couldn�t for fear of what would happen if 
she DID say something. Tavatron continued to gaze into the beyond, almost 
not hearing Dinobot�s reluctant apology.

Tavatron�s ears perked and swiveled in his direction at the words and 
�apology� and �you may have it�. She was speechless. This, of all things, 
was the absolutely LAST thing she had ever expected to hear from the stoic 
warrior. Perhaps he had softened a bit since she met him. He wasn�t weak, 
no, far from it. He was, however, becoming compassionate, even if he was 
unwilling to admit it.

"That was a very�"

Tavarton thought for a moment, unsure of what to say. He unfinished sentence 
hung in the air before her like so many things she had yet to accomplish. 
This one task, however, was something she was sure she could complete.

"�honorable thing to do. Thank you."

Tavatron fell to her back with a soft thud. One leg still hung over the 
cliff�s edge, but her upper body was no longer upright. She crossed her arms 
and rested her head on top of them. The small dust cloud that formed around 
her quickly dissipated. She looked up and over at the bottom of Dinobot�s 
jaw and underbelly, right now that was all she could see of him in this 
position. Her voice had grown quiet and somewhat subdued as she spoke:

"I am disappointed in myself as well."

Tavatron took a deep breath. Only the survivors of the incident on the 
colony had known of what occured there. Should she tell him? Something told 
her she could trust him, but still�

First, there was something she had to know:

"Dinobot, why did you follow me? I know this is against your nature, so 
don�t try to rationalize that it isn�t."

She didn�t mean to sound demanding, but she had to know why he came after 
her. She would have bet her life savings that he would say to the pit with 
her and left her out here to rot. She just had to know.  A sudden cawing of 
birds drew Tavatron�s attention skyward as they took off in a black cloud of 
feathers. There was something beyond them, she could see it out of the 
corner of her eye. It was shooting across the sky, but a sudden growing in 
the intensity of the birds� cawing drew her attention from the object. When 
she looked again it had vanished. No matter, it was probably nothing 
important anyway. Perhaps she was just seeing things.
